ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
Indeed, know that arrogance [kibr] is among the destroyers, and no one among creation is free from some measure of it. Its removal is an individual obligation [fard 'ayn], and it is not removed by mere wishing, but rather by treatment and the application of remedies that suppress it. In its treatment are two stations: the first is the eradication of its root from its origin and the uprooting of its tree from its planting in the heart [qalb]. The first station is in eradicating its root, and its treatment is both intellectual ['ilmi] and practical ['amali], and healing is not complete except by their combination. As for the intellectual: it is that he knows himself and knows his Lord, the Most High, and that suffices him in removing arrogance [kibr]. For whenever he knows himself with true knowledge [ma'rifa], he knows that he is more abased than every abased one and lesser than every small thing, and that nothing befits him except humility [tawadu'], abasement [dhilla], and lowliness. And when he knows his Lord, he knows that grandeur ['azama] and majesty [kibriya'] are only befitting for Allah. As for knowing himself, that is also lengthy, but we mention from it what is beneficial in arousing humility [tawadu'] and abasement [dhilla]. It suffices him to know the meaning of a single verse in the Book of Allah, for the Qur'an is the knowledge ['ilm] of the first and the last for one whose insight [basira] has been opened. And He, the Most High, has said: "Perished is man [insan]; how ungrateful he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the way easy for him. Then He causes him to die and puts him in a grave. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." (76:1-3) The verse has pointed to the first creation of man [insan]: he was not a thing mentioned, and he was in the realm of non-existence for agesâ€”indeed, his non-existence had no beginning. And what thing is more vile and lesser than obliteration and non-existence? He was like that in pre-eternity. Then Allah created him from the vilest of things, then from the filthiest of them, for He created him from dust, then from a sperm-drop [nutfa], then from a clinging clot ['alaqa], then from a lump of flesh [mudgha], then He made him bones, then He clothed the bones with flesh. This was the beginning of his existence, when he became a thing mentioned. He did not become a thing mentioned except while being upon the vilest of descriptions and attributes! For he was not created complete at his beginning; rather, He created him as an inanimate, dead thingâ€”he did not hear, nor see, nor feel, nor move, nor speak, nor grasp, nor perceive, nor know. He began with his death before his life, and with his weakness before his strength, and with his ignorance before his knowledge ['ilm], and with his blindness before his sight, and with his deafness before his hearing, and with his muteness before his speech, and with his misguidance before his guidance, and with his poverty before his wealth, and with his incapacity before his power. This is the meaning of His saying: "From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed?" (76:2) and the meaning of His saying: "Has there [not] come upon man [insan] a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned? Indeed, We created man [insan] from a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed that We may try him..." (76:1-2) Thus He created him first, then bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Then He made the way easy for him." (76:3) This is a reference to what was facilitated for him during the period of his life until death. And similarly He said: "From a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed that We may try him; so We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We guided him to the way, be he grateful or be he ungrateful." (76:2-3) Its meaning is that He gave him life after he was an inanimate, dead thingâ€”dust first and a sperm-drop [nutfa] second. And He gave him hearing after he was deaf, and sight after he was lacking vision, and strength after weakness, and knowledge ['ilm] after ignorance, and created for him limbs with their wonders and signs after their absence, and enriched him after poverty, and satiated him after hunger, and clothed him after nakedness, and guided him after misguidance. So look how He managed him and formed him, and to the way how He made it easy, and to the transgression of man [insan]â€”how ungrateful he is!â€”and to the ignorance of man [insan] how He made it manifest? So He said: "Does not man [insan] see that We created him from a sperm-drop [nutfa]? And at once he is a clear adversary. And of His signs is that He created you from dust; then, suddenly you were human beings dispersing [throughout the earth]." (36:77, 30:20) So look at the favor [ni'ma] of Allah upon him, how He transferred him from that abasement [dhilla], insignificance, vileness, and filth to this elevation and honor, so he became existent after non-existence, alive after death, speaking after muteness, seeing after blindness, strong after weakness, knowing after ignorance, guided after misguidance, capable after incapacity, and rich after poverty? He was, in his essence, nothing. And what thing is viler than nothing? And what insignificance is less than pure non-existence? Then he became, by Allah, a thing. He only created him from the abased dust [turab] that is trodden underfoot and the filthy sperm-drop [nutfa] after pure non-existence also to make him know the vileness of his essence, so that he may know himself by it. And He only perfected the favor [ni'ma] upon him so that he may know his Lord by it and know by it His grandeur ['azama] and majesty [jalal], and that majesty [kibriya'] is only befitting for Him, Glorified and Exalted. And for that reason, He bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Have We not made for him two eyes and a tongue and two lips? And have shown him the two ways?" (90:8-10) And He made known his vileness first, saying: "Was he not a sperm-drop [nutfa] from semen emitted? Then he was a clinging clot ['alaqa]..." (75:37-38) Then He mentioned His favor [minna] upon him, saying: "Then He created and proportioned. And made from him the two sexes, male and female." (75:38-39) So that his existence may continue through procreation, just as his existence first occurred through invention. So, one whose beginning is this and whose states are theseâ€”from where does he get pride, arrogance [kibr], boasting, and haughtiness, when he is, in truth, the vilest of the vile and the weakest of the weak?

Indeed, love [mahabba] and intimate communion [uns] with God, the Exalted, are not attained except through the perpetual remembrance [dhikr] of the Beloved and constant adherence to it. And knowledge [ma'rifa] of Him is not realized except through the total absorption of thought [fikr] in His Essence, His Attributes, and His Actions, for there is nothing in existence besides Him and His actions. And the continuity of remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] will not be facilitated except by abandoning the world [dunya] and its desires, and restricting oneself from it to the measure of necessity. And that is not accomplished except by occupying all the times of night and day with the duties of remembrances [adhkar] and contemplations [afkar]. The soul [nafs], due to what it is created upon of weariness and boredom, does not have patience for a single pattern of the means of remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr]. Rather, if it is returned to it, it shows aversion. And God, the Exalted, does not tire until you tire. So from the necessity of gentleness with it is to refresh it by moving from one mode to another and from one type to another according to each time, so that its pleasure [ladhdha] increases through the transition, its desire [raghba] is magnified by the pleasure, and its adherence [muwazaba] endures through the endurance of the desire. For that reason, the litanies [awrad] are divided into different divisions. And it is necessary that remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] occupy all times or most of them. For the soul [nafs], by its nature, is inclined to the pleasures [ladhadh] of the world [dunya]. So if the servant spends half of his times on the arrangements and permissible desires of the world [dunya] and the other half on acts of worship, the side of inclination to the world [dunya] outweighs due to its conformity with nature [tab'], since the time is equal. So how can they be balanced when nature [tab'] gives weight to one of them? For the outward and inward assist each other in the matters of the world [dunya], and the heart [qalb] becomes pure and single-minded in seeking it. As for being turned back to acts of worship, it is forced, and the sincerity [ikhlas] and presence [hudur] of the heart [qalb] in it are not safe except at some times. So whoever wishes to enter Paradise without reckoning, let him occupy all his times in obedience [ta'a]. And whoever wishes for the scale of his good deeds to outweigh and the balances of his goodness to be heavy, let him occupy most of his times in obedience [ta'a]. If he mixes a righteous deed with another that is evil, then his affair is perilous. But hope is not cut off, and pardon from the generosity of God is awaited. Perhaps God, the Exalted, will forgive him by His bounty and generosity. This is what has been unveiled to the observers by the light of insight [basira]. If you are not of its people, then look at the address of God, the Exalted, to His Messenger and take it by the light of faith [iman]. For God, the Exalted, has said: **"And remember the name of your Lord morning and evening, and during the night prostrate to Him and glorify Him a long night."** This indicates that the path to God, the Exalted, is the vigilance over times and populating them with litanies [awrad] in a manner of continuity, to achieve the continuity of remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] in all periods of night and day. Thus the heart [qalb] becomes occupied with intimate communion [uns] and love [mahabba], detached from the pleasures of the world [dunya], and absorbed in seeking the Countenance of the Most Generous.
